revision.comment: Removing AfD tag, the result was keep
revision.text:
'''Queeruption''' (a compound of ''[[queer]]'' and ''[[eruption]]'')<ref name=brown>{{cite journal|last=Brown|first=Gavin|title=Mutinous eruptions: autonomous spaces of radical queer activism|journal=Environment and Planning|year=2007|volume=39|issue=11|pages=2685 – 2698|doi=10.1068/a38385|url=http://envplan.com/abstract.cgi?id=a38385}}</ref> is an annual international [[queercore]] festival and gathering started in 1998 where alternative/radical/disenfranchised [[queer]]s can exchange information, network, organize, inspire and get inspired, self-represent, and challenge mainstream society with do-it-yourself ([[DIY ethic|DIY]]) ideas and ethics.<ref name=sfbg>{{cite news|title=8 Days a Week|url=http://www.sfbg.com/39/30/x_8days.html|accessdate=26 September 2012|newspaper=SF Bay Guardian|date=April 27 - May 4, 2005}}</ref><ref name=vanes>{{cite news|last=Vaneslander|first=B.|title=Long Live Temporariness: Two Queer Examples of Autonomous Spaces|url=http://affinitiesjournal.org/affinities/index.php/affinities/article/view/3/41|accessdate=26 September 2012|newspaper=Affinities Journal|date=Vol 1, No 1 (2007)}}</ref><ref name=AJ>{{cite journal|coauthors=Richard J.F. Day and Sarita Srivastava|title=Journal Editors’ Introduction|journal=Affinities: a Journal of Radical Theory,Culture, and Action|year=2007|accessdate=26 September 2012|location=[http://www.rorta.net/textfiles/affinities.vol.1.no.1.(2007).pdf Affinities: a Journal of Radical Theory,Culture, and Action]}}</ref> Shows featuring queer [[punk music|punk]] bands, [[performance art]]ists, and other entertainment are put on at night, while workshops and demonstrations take place during the daytime.<ref name=vanes/><ref name=AJ/><ref>{{cite news|last=Mittelmann|first=Laurie|title=He’s taking action to make the impossible possible|url=http://www.thevillager.com/villager_269/hestakingaction.html|accessdate=26 September 2012|newspaper=The Villager|date=Volume 78 / Number 4 - June 25 - July 1, 2008}}</ref> Queeruption generally takes place in a different city in a different country every year.<ref name=vanes/><ref name=AJ/> It has contributed to [[anarcho-queer]] (queer anarchist) movements.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hekma|first=Gert|title=Book Review: Anarchism & Sexuality. Ethics, Relationships and Power|journal=Journal of Homosexuality|date=15 May 2012|year=2012|volume=59|issue=5|pages=757-759|doi=10.1080/00918369.2012.673949|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00918369.2012.673949|editor1-last=Jamie Heckert and Richard Cleminson|location=Abingdon, UK}}</ref> The groups that organize each event and even within the same city may have disagreements about how aspects should represent politics including queer [[safe space]]s.<ref>{{cite book|last=Haworth|first=Robert H.|title=Anarchist Pedagogies: Collective Actions, Theories, and Critical Reflections on Education|year=2012|publisher=PM Press|isbn=PM Press|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=3BSVEm5mQ-sC}}</ref>
From their 2003 announcement. "Queeruption is non-commercial! Queeruption is Do-it-Yourself! We draw no line between organisers and participants. We seek to provide a framework (space, co-ordination) which you can fill with your ideas. It will include workshops, music, demonstrations, film, art, performances, (sex) parties, picnics, games and any other activities your feel like trying! What is queeruption? What is queer culture? For expression and exploration of identity. Climbing over the artificial boundaries of sexuality, gender, nation, class! Against racism, capitalism, patriarchy and binary gender repression."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Poldervaart|first=Saskia|title=Utopianism and Sexual Politics In Dutch Social Movements (1830-2003)|year=2004|volume=Past and Present of Radical Sexual Politics|pages=122-132|url=http://socialhistory.org/sites/default/files/docs/poldervaart-2003.doc|publisher=Mosse Foundation|location=Amsterdam}}</ref>
==List of gatherings== * Queeruption 1 (1998) [[London]] * Queeruption 2 (1999) [[New York City]] * Queeruption 3 (2001) [[San Francisco]] * Queeruption 4 (2002) [[London]]<ref name=brown/> * Queeruption 5 (2003) [[Berlin]] * Queeruption 6 (2004) [[Amsterdam]] * Queeruption 7 (2005) [[Sydney]] * Queeruption 8 (2005) [[Barcelona]]<ref name=sfbg/><ref name=vanes/> * Queeruption 9 (2006) [[Tel-Aviv]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Svirsky|first=Gila|title=Pride and No-pride|url=http://www.opednews.com/articles/genera_gila_svi_060812_war___nyet_21__ceasefi.htm|publisher=OEN|accessdate=26 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Kouri-Towe|first=Natalie|coauthors=Carrie Rentschler|title=War and pride: "Out Against the Occupation" and queer responses to the 2006 Lebanon War|year=2008|publisher=McGill University|location=McGill University's Institutional Repository (Canada)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wagner|first=Roy|title=Sexual and National Mobility-Visibility Regimes In Israel/Palestine, And How To Cross Through Them|url=http://hug-web.at/drupal/sites/default/files/down/activist-media-and-biopolitics.pdf#page=67|publisher=Activist Media and Biopolitics|accessdate=26 September 2012}}</ref> * Queeruption 10 (2007) [[Vancouver]] * [http://queeruption.org.uk/ Queeruption 11] 2010 [[Manchester]]
==See also== {{Portal|LGBT}} * [[Ladyfest]] * [[Queer]] * [[Queer Mutiny]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://queeruption.tribe.net/ An international tribe for queerupters worldwide]
